paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet on a very short, tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf, retain an atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b System
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Single planet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The observed rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve, providing thermal phase variation and spectral structure around the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock Null Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A pure no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, serving as the null hypothesis to test whether an atmosphere is required to explain the observations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly targeting the CO2 spectral feature near 15 um to assess whether carbon dioxide can explain the observed spectral structure.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized atmospheric composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative composition that could also potentially match the data.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions including circulation models, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors and could bias results.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features, introducing uncertainty into the detection claims.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset due to observational geometry.
Degeneracies between atmospheric composition, cloud/haze properties, and circulation assumptions remain significant and limit compositional constraints.
